title: 106_s148
content:
The Act is titled the "Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act". Congress finds that approximately 500 bird species in the United States migrate to Latin America and the Caribbean, providing valuable benefits. Many of these species are declining due to habitat loss and pollution. Conservation efforts require collaboration among countries along their migration routes. Conservation efforts for migratory birds require collaboration among countries along their migration routes and can be strengthened by increased coordination. The purposes of this Act are to perpetuate healthy populations of neotropical migratory birds, support conservation initiatives in the United States, Latin America, and the Caribbean, and provide financial resources for international cooperation. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS.

In this Act:
(1) Account.--The term ``Account'' means the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account established by section 9(a).
(2) Conservation.--The term ``conservation'' means methods necessary to ensure the long-term viability of neotropical migratory bird species, including population protection, habitat management, research, law enforcement, and community outreach.
(3) Secretary.--The term ``Secretary'' means the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary will establish a program to provide financial assistance for projects promoting the conservation of neotropical migratory birds. Project proposals can be submitted by various entities, including individuals, government agencies, and international organizations. Proposals must include the project leader's name and a brief statement of the project's goals. Under this Act, project applicants must submit a proposal that includes the project leader's name, project goals, qualifications of project staff, estimated funds and time needed, sources of matching funds, and a focus on conserving neotropical migratory bird species. The project must involve local public participation, consultation with wildlife management authorities, sensitivity to cultural resources, and promotion of sustainability. The project proposal must demonstrate sensitivity to local historic and cultural resources, promote sustainable conservation programs for neotropical migratory birds, and provide necessary information for evaluation. Recipients must submit periodic reports to the Secretary for project progress assessment. The Federal share of project costs should not exceed 25%, and non-Federal funding sources cannot come from Federal grant programs. The non-Federal share for a project must not come from Federal grant programs. In the United States, it must be paid in cash, while in foreign countries, it can be paid in cash or in kind. The Secretary's duties under the Act include developing guidelines for project proposals, encouraging submissions from wildlife management authorities, selecting proposals that meet requirements and conservation needs, and implementing the Act. Cooperation is also emphasized. The Secretary shall support and coordinate efforts to conserve neotropical migratory bird species by facilitating meetings, exchanging information, entering agreements, and coordinating activities with existing conservation projects. An advisory group may be convened to assist in these efforts. The Secretary may convene an advisory group of individuals from public and private organizations involved in neotropical migratory bird conservation. The group must hold open meetings, provide opportunities for public input, give timely notice of meetings, keep minutes, and is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress by October 1, 2002, on the program's results and effectiveness under this Act, with recommendations for improvement and whether the program should continue. Additionally, there is a Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account established. The Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account is established within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund of the Treasury. The Secretary of the Treasury will deposit donations and appropriated amounts into the Account. The Secretary can use the funds for the Act's implementation, with a limit of 3% or $80,000 for administrative expenses. Donations can also be accepted and used for the Act's purposes. The Secretary can accept donations for implementing the Act, with funds transferred to the Treasury for deposit into the Account. Authorization of appropriations for the Account to carry out the Act is set at $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005, with a requirement that at least 75 percent of the funds be used for projects outside the United States.
